interlinear-text.item: Recounted in 1968 by Akramcho Soultonov, 50 years old, Kolkhazian from the village of Zmoudg.

phrase.item: Whether this is true or not, there once was an old woman.
She had a ewe.
On the rare day that it came time to shear her, the old woman began to shear her when she felt the need to unrinate.
She says, “As long as I have not finished shearing her, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
She shears her completely then starts to card the wool,
and again feels the need to urinate.
“As long as I have not finished carding her, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
So she starts to beat the wool.
She starts to beat the wool, and again feels the need to piss.
‎‎She says, “As long as I have not finished scutching the wool, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
She starts threading the wool.
She threads half the wool when she feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not finished threading, I won’t go out into the courtyard.
She starts to spin.
She spins half when again she feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not spun everything, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
She finishes spinning and starts unwinding.
She gets halfway through when again she feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not spooled it all, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
Then she starts stretching the frame on the loom.
She gets halfway through and again feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not attached it all, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
So she starts weaving.
She weaves half of it when again she feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not finished weaving, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
The weaving finished, she starts to wash it,
washes half and again feels the need to urinate.
She says, as long as I have not finished washing, I won’t go out into the courtyard.
Having finished washing, she begins to cut.
She cuts half when she feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not finished cutting, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
Once the cut is finished, she begins to sew.
Halfway through she feels the need to urinate.
She says, “As long as I have not finished sewing, I won’t go out into the courtyard.”
After sewing, she gets dressed and goes on a rock.
There she squats, urinates, and from her urine shoots up a bouquet of fruit trees. Now she begins to search for a gardener. She goes to look for a gardener and a magpie finds her.
miwaoTish?
The magpie finds her and says, “Hey, old woman, where are you going?”
She says, “I’m looking for a gardener.”
The magpie says, “I would make a good gardener.”
The old woman says, “And what will you say at my garden?”
The magpie says, “I’ll say at your garden: 'Chakhwakh, old women, torn vagina, old women.'"
The old woman says, “You won’t do.”
She walks, and a crow meets her and says, “Hey, old woman, where are you going?”
She says, “I’m looking for a gardener.”
The crow says, I would make a good gardener.”
The old woman says, “And what will you say at my garden?”
The crow says, “I’ll say at your garden: 'Qawqaw of old women, torn vagina, old women'"
The old woman beats it, scolds it,
and says, “You won’t do.”
She goes looking for a gardener. A sparrow meets her.
A sparrow meets her and says, "Hey, old woman, where are you going?"
She says, “I’m looking for a gardener.”
The sparrow says, "I would make a good gardener.”
The old woman says, “And what will you say at my garden?”
The sparrow says, “I would arrive and say: 'Chirping of sparrows, gardener for old women".
And the old woman takes it and places it in her garden.
One day, the king passes through this parade to go hunting.
He goes hunting, sees the garden and says, “Whose is this?”
The sparrow says: "Chirping of sparrows.
Gardener for old women"
The king arrives at the village and says, “What is my kingdom if in this orchard, my name is not spoken, a sparrow says the name of an old woman!”
He orders his servants to go kill her.
What's the -i in kanizəkəvi (also see 8.10, same but without the diminutive)
The servants go look for the old woman, but don’t find her, they seize the sparrow and bring it.
The king says: “Tear off its wings”.
They tear the wings off the sparrow, but it says, “I had wings, I no longer do.”
The vowels for the Persian are wrong, but it is Persian: "pardār būdam, bēpar šudam" ("I was winged, I became wingless").
The king says, “Cut off its head!”
They cut off his head, but it says, “I had a head, I no longer do.”
"sardār būdam, bēsar šudam" ("I had a head, I became headless").
The king says, cut it into pieces!”
They cut it into pieces, but it says, “I was big, I became very small.”
‎‎"kalān būdam, mVyda šudam" ("I was huge, I became little pieces").
The king says, “Fry it!”
They fry it in the hearth, but it says, “I was raw, I am cooked.” They bring it, the king eats it, and then begins to have a stomach ache.”
"xām būdam, puxta šudam"
His stomach starts to pain him, and the king calls his servants, “Come around me, because it is going to fly away in a moment.”
The sparrow flies away. The royal servants pull out their swords, but the sparrow already took flight, and the king’s posterior bursts in two.
